sections.title: Sinus lift for dental implants in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.body: A sinus lift is a grafting procedure used in the upper back jaw when the sinus space and available bone height limit implant placement. Planning is central. We use CBCT imaging to measure bone levels, assess sinus anatomy, and decide whether a small internal lift can be carried out at the time of implant placement or whether a staged approach is safer. We’ll explain healing times, how this may affect the overall timeline, and what recovery typically involves. Not every case requires a sinus lift. Where it is not appropriate, we discuss alternatives such as shorter implants or different implant positions.

sections.title: Creating space for stable upper implants
sections.body: A sinus lift increases the available bone height in the upper back jaw. The sinus membrane is gently raised and graft material is placed beneath it. This creates the support needed for an implant where natural bone is limited. Many patients do not need this procedure. Imaging determines suitability.

sections.title: Who might need a sinus lift?
items: Missing upper back teeth for a prolonged period
Reduced bone height beneath the sinus
Situations where added support improves implant stability
Many implant patients don’t require a sinus lift — scans confirm this

sections.title: Questions about sinus lifts and implants

faqs.question: Do I often need a sinus lift for upper implants?
faqs.answer: No. A sinus lift is only advised when scans show it would improve implant stability.

faqs.question: Is a sinus lift painful?
faqs.answer: Treatment is carried out with local anaesthetic. Some soreness afterwards is normal.

faqs.question: How long does healing take?
faqs.answer: Healing times vary by case and are reviewed before moving to implant placement.

faqs.question: Can I have temporary teeth while healing?
faqs.answer: In many situations, a temporary option can be discussed to maintain appearance during healing.

faqs.question: Are there alternatives to a sinus lift?
faqs.answer: Sometimes shorter implants or modified implant positions may be possible. Options are reviewed after imaging.

faqs.question: What are the risks?
faqs.answer: Risks may include swelling, sinus discomfort, or delayed graft healing. These are explained and monitored.

faqs.question: Will it delay my implant treatment?
faqs.answer: A healing phase is usually required before implant placement. Timelines are discussed in advance.

faqs.question: How much does a sinus lift cost?
faqs.answer: Costs depend on complexity and staging. A written plan with fees is provided after assessment.

sections.title: When this fits and what else to consider
sections.body: Sinus lift decisions follow careful implant assessment. Imaging, bone levels, and overall treatment aims determine whether grafting is sensible or whether alternatives provide a safer route.

sections.title: Unsure whether a sinus lift is needed?
sections.strapline: Book an implant assessment in Shoreham-by-Sea and we’ll explain what’s necessary — and what isn’t — based on imaging.
